conclusion: The acceleration-time graph shows how acceleration varies over time. The body starts from rest (initial velocity v₀ = 0). Positive direction is the direction of initial motion.

Velocity is the integral of acceleration over time: v(t) = v₀ + ∫a(t)dt. When acceleration is positive, velocity increases. When acceleration is negative, velocity decreases. Maximum velocity occurs when acceleration changes from positive to negative.
From t = 0 to t = 1s: a = 2 m/s² (constant positive).
From t = 1s to t = 2s: a decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0 m/s².
From t = 2s to t = 3s: a decreases linearly from 0 m/s² to -2 m/s².
From t = 3s to t = 4s: a = -2 m/s² (constant negative).

premise: The velocity will be maximum when the acceleration changes from positive to negative, which is when acceleration becomes zero.
conclusion: Looking at the graph, this occurs at t = 2s.

premise: Before t = 2s: acceleration is positive, so velocity is increasing. After t = 2s: acceleration is negative, so velocity is decreasing. At t = 2s: acceleration is exactly zero, marking the transition point.
conclusion: The object's velocity is at its maximum at t = 2 seconds.
